# Personal projects
This repo contains personal projects with application of Machine learning and Exploratory Data Analysis. Currently there are 5 projects. If there are issues rendering bigger jupiter notebooks, please, use <a href="https://nbviewer.jupyter.org/">nbviewer</a>.
_______
### Predicting Propensity to Buy New Products or Services(Appetency). Case of Highly Imbalanced Data.
<img align="right" width="250" hight="200" src="data:image/jpeg;base64,">

<font size="+1">Overview:</font>

 <a href="https://www.kdd.org/kdd-cup/view/kdd-cup-2009/Intro">Data</a> is taken from KDD cup challenge and represents a large marketing database from the French Telecom company Orange. There are 50k data entires and 230 anonymised features. Data is very sparse and contains a lot of missing values (including 100% missing values in some of the features). 
 
The <i>challenge is</i> to predict target variable which has a high imbalance (only 1.78% of positive labels). Here I'm trying different algorithms and resampling techniques to see which ones perform better.

<details> 
<summary> <b>See main findings!</b></summary>
<br>

I tried several algorithms, starting with the a simple Logistic Regression and moving into bagging and boosting techniques. I also tried fine tuning models to specifically adapt for imbalanced data, as well as using <b>oversampling, undersampling and SMOTE</b> to combat imabalance. Finally, I tried to see whether <b>Mahalanobis distance</b> might work as a good predictor of the anomaly class.
    
Resampling techniques prroved to be extremely important in modelling churn. Imbalance was stark - even after preprosessing data and filling in missing values there were only 2.8% positive labels! Because of that all <b>baseline models performed extremely poorly - AUC was 0.5, recall and precision were 0</b>, the model was determining all the test observations as people from the majority class. 

<b>In terms of the dealing with the imbalance the efficiency was the following</b>:
- adding class_weights (did not change the performance, AUC - 0.5);
- oversampling the minority class (decreased the performance, AUC - 0.4974);
- SMOTE (improved the performance slightly, AUC - 0.5022)
- undersampling the majority class(improved the performance significantly, AUC - 0.7016);

In terms of the classifiers the <b>best performance was achieved by CatBoost (AUC - 0.7565) and LGBM(AUC - 0.7562)</b>, then RandomForest (AUC - 0.7490), then XGBoost(AUC - 0.7462), the simplest Logit (AUC - 0.7345). Given that initial dataset had the majority of columns with all the data missing, it might explain not high metrics.

Applying PCA, MinMaxScaler, Mahalanobis distance did not achieve high results as well. 

Leaving the existing features with very high number of NAs seemed to work the best as there was a <b>clear indication that the positive class was more frequent among variables with high number of NAs.</b>

</details>


|[Go see full project!](https://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/kate-chunosova/Personal_projects/blob/master/Appetency%2C%20orange/Appetency_orange.ipynb)|
|---|

### (Ave) Churn, or Exploring Churn, Segmenting Typical Churners and Automating Churn Prediction.

<img align="right" width="250" height="200" src="https://cdn.technologyadvice.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/6-Ways-CRM-Stop-Customer-Churn.png">

   <font size="+1">Overview:</font>

Telephone service companies, Internet service providers, pay TV companies, insurance firms and others often use customer attrition rates as one of their key business metrics because the cost of retaining an existing customer is far less than acquiring a new one. Companies from these sectors often have customer service branches which attempt to win back defecting clients, because recovered long-term customers can be worth much more to a company than newly recruited clients. 

In this project I'm taking a closer look at the following:
- churn rates;
- what are the factors that increase probability of churn;
- what are segments of typical churner, their attributes;
- ways in which we can target churners clusters to prevent them from leaving us

I'm also using Machine Learning to create a model that's gonna help predict potential churners so that we can target them beforehand.</u>

<a href="https://www.kaggle.com/puja19/telcom-customer-churn">Data</a> is taken from Kaggle platform and represents Telco client database with demographic characteristics, extra telco services used by customers, details of their current contract, charges to their account.
<details> 
<summary> <b>See main findings!</b></summary>
<br>

Current churn rate is 26.5%, meaning that 1 in 4 customers leaves us. Preliminary analysis showed that the majority of people who leave have very low Total Charges which may imply that <b>we're loosing a lot of customers on early stages</b>. There are a lot of <b>people who leave us because of high Monthly Charges</b> as well. 
    
It was crucial for me to consider two points:
- <b>The size of the targeted group</b>;
- <b>Propensity to churn within the group</b>. 

Knowing those features we can prioritize our marketing actions in order to achieve the best efficiency given certain cost on retaining the clients. If we find that customers belonging to a particular demographic or other group tend to churn more, <b>we should first target the big groups with the higher propensity to churn and only then spend the rest of the marketing budget on small groups of our clients that leave us</b>.
    
<b>Several insights on who churns</b>:
    
- Churn doesn't seem to differ between gender;
- There are few senior customers in our business, however, they seem to have a significantly higher churn rate;
- People without a partner seem to churn more than people without;
- People without dependents tend to churn twice as much as people with them;
- Highest churn is with customers who have Fiber Optic services, which is supposed to provide fastest connection (issue with the quality/speed?)
    - 30% of people who use Streaming services churn and half of those people use Fiber Optics - looks like if we improve it, we'll save ourselves a lot of customers!
- A lot of churners among people with no Online Security, no Device Protection, no Tech Support and no Online Backup (makes sense - those willing to subscribe to extra services are more loyal, they aren't going to leave unless extra services are very bad);

    
Next, I decided to look cluster our churners to define homogenous groups easier to target. <i>I used OPTICS clustering algorithm to find clusters among those who churn.</i> Resulting clusters:
    
<table>
  <thead>
    <tr>
      <th><b>"The majority a.k.a infamous Fiber connection guys"</b></th>
      <th><b>Reccomendations</b></th>
    </tr>
  </thead>
  <tbody>
    <tr>
      <td>Represents 85% of churners</td>
      <td>Look into Fiber connection, the speed or connection are not good</td>
    </tr>    
    <tr>
      <td>Consists mostly of females in contrast with other two clusters</td>
      <td>Monthly charges seem to be 30% higher than the average of those customers who don't churn - either decrease monthy charges or provide better quality services</td>
    </tr>   
    <tr>
      <td>Subscribed to Multiple Lines and Fiber Optic internet</td>
      <td>Push Online backup, security, device protection services</td>
    </tr>   
    <tr>
      <td>Higher tenure, Montly and Total Charges</td>
      <td> </td>
    </tr>
  </tbody>
</table>

    
<table>
  <thead>
    <tr>
      <th><b>"DSL guys"</b></th>
      <th><b>Reccomendations</b></th>
    </tr>
  </thead>
  <tbody>

      <td>Represents 9% of churners</td>
      <td>Push Streaming services</td>

      <td> </td>
    </tr>
  </tbody>
</table>
   

<table>
  <thead>
    <tr>
      <th><b>"Phony guys"</b></th>
      <th><b>Reccomendations</b></th>
    </tr>
  </thead>
  <tbody>
    <tr>
      <td>Represents 6% of churners</td>
      <td>Try to sell our internet service, push DSL one</td>
    </tr>    
    <tr>
      <td>Don't have Multiple Lines and internet service</td>
      <td>Push Online backup, security, device protection services</td>
    </tr>   
    <tr>
      <td>Have DSL internet connection</td>
      <td> </td>
    </tr>   
    <tr>
      <td>Pay with mailed check</td>
      <td> </td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td>Only use our Phone Services</td>
      <td> </td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td>Extremely low Total, Montly Charges and tenure</td>
      <td> </td>
    </tr>
  </tbody>
</table>

<i>For automating prediction</i> I checked several algorithms namely Logistic Regression, Naive Bayes, XGBoost and Random Forest. The best model to predict turned out to be Random Forest Classifier, it gives F1-score of 0.636, precision of 55% and recall of 76%.
 
</details>

|[Go see full project!](https://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/kate-chunosova/Personal_projects/blob/master/Churn%2C%20telecom/Churn_analysis.ipynb)|

### Prevailing Fake News with NLP.

<img align="right" width="250" hight="200" src="https://i.pinimg.com/originals/e4/c5/9b/e4c59bcdc46d056a9bac125251ea63a3.jpg">

<font size="+1">Overview:</font>

This is a classification problem, the challenge is to predict target class (Fake or Real). Data is first cleaned, next some extra features are generated (including POS-tagging), alongside with conversion of the text corpus into a TF-IDF matrix to further feed it into ML algorithm. Here I experimented with how n-gramms, POS-tagging, lemmatization and stemming, elimination of stop words impact final results.
<details> 
<summary> <b>See main findings!</b></summary>
<br>

The dataset was balanced, so there was no need to take extra steps to tackle this issue. EDA showed that presence of emoji in the article text was more present in Fake news rather than in Real articles. Some <b>additional features created involved count of words in the article, in its title, number of stopwords, uppercase words</b>. However, those could not provide a very clear separation between the classes.

I also ran a quick sentiment analysis which showed that <b>articles with very positive or very negative sentiment almost exclusively tended to be Fake news</b> which makes sense since fake news usually aim at extreme, shoking content.
    
I started my modeling with Naive Bayes which proved to be a good baseline for text classification purposes, baseline accuracy was 88%. I experimented with CountVectorizer, TF-IDF, as well as tried Logit which performed more or less the same. I also tried both stemming and lemmatization, the latter seemed to work better, although predictably slower. I tried uni-grams, bi-grams, three-grams.
    
<b>Final model was achieved with stopwords, lemmatization, using bigrams and engeneered features. POS-tagging prooved to be useful. Final accuracy is 93% using Logistic Regression algorithm.</b>


</details>


|[Go see full project!](https://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/kate-chunosova/Personal_projects/blob/master/Fake_news_classification/Fake_news.ipynb)|
|---|

### Packaging Machine Learning Model for Bike Rentals Prediction and Creating a Simple Flask App.

<img align="right" width="200" src="https://cdn.auth0.com/blog/illustration/angular-python-flask.png">

<font size="+1">Overview:</font>

This project's goal was to package a previously created model for predicting number of bikes rented on a given hour. The reference jupiter notebook with data exploration and more detailed explanation of ML pipeline can be found [here](https://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/kate-chunosova/Personal_projects/blob/master/Packaging_ML_Model/reference/3_Bike-Sharing_GroupE.ipynb). Next step was to use Flask API, so that given modified user requests the page would show a correct prediction given input features.

[See instructions to install the package!](https://github.com/kate-chunosova/Personal_projects/blob/master/Packaging_ML_Model/README_1.md)

[See instructions to run the flask app!](https://github.com/kate-chunosova/Personal_projects/blob/master/Packaging_ML_Model/README_2.md)


|[Go see full project!](https://github.com/kate-chunosova/Personal_projects/tree/master/Packaging_ML_Model)|

### YouTube Russian Video Analysis.

<img align="right" width="250" hight="300" src="https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/3zkP2SYe7yYoKKe47bsNe44yTgb4Ukh__rBbwXwgkjNRe4PykGG409ozBxzxkrubV7zHKjfxq6y9ShogWtMBMPyB3jiNps91LoNH8A=s500">

<font size="+1">Overview:</font>

Being an avid user of YouTube and a russian, I decided to take a look at what videos are popular among my fellow compatriots. In this EDA notebook I try to shed light on several questions:

1. Correlation between likes, views, comments and dislikes
2. Top 10 most viewed, liked, disliked, commented videos, most popular channels
3. What are the most posted/viewed/commented/liked/disliked categories?
4. Engagement metrics per category: what are the categories that viewers like or hate the most?
5. How long are the videos trending and what are the most and longest trending cetegories?
6. Most popular tags and words in description, most popular tags in the most disliked category. 
7. Which are the videos which are removed or have disabled comments or ratings?

<details> 
<summary> <i>TLDP</i></summary>
<br>
I also wanted to look at the sentiment analysis of the comment section or text description in order to gauge how friendly and positive our people are on the platform (possibly unveiling the myth that russians are those never smiling, leaning on the negative side people). However, I ran into technical issues with installing sentiment analysis library Dostoevsky. I've tried everything that could be done to salvage the situation, the next possible actions require for me to make a system update of OSX which I'm currently not mentally ready to do. However, this could be a nice possible TO DO for this project.
    
</details>

  
<details> 
<summary> <b>See main findings!</b></summary>
<br>

- The <b>most viewed</b> and liked videos are mostly MVs or movie trailers
- Almost all of the <b>most disliked</b> videos refer to politics (opposition, Navalnyi, elections, protests)
- The <b>most commented</b> videos are not the political ones (except for 1 video). Seems like people tend to just hit dislike button without engaging much in the discussion
- The <b>most posted number of videos</b> were dedicated to People & Blogs, other notable categories - Entertainment and News & Politics. <b>The least number of posts</b> belongs to Movies, Travel and Shows.
- Despite the fact that <b>MVs</b> are far from the most posted videos, they have the highest mean number of views, comments, likes and dislikes, meaning that they <b>are the most user engaging category</b>. At the same time being <b>the most posted category, People and Blogs, does not attract as many viewers</b>.
- Russian users for some reason seem to <b>dislike comedy videos (looks like we have tough sense of humour)</b>. Nonprofits videos also seem to be highly disliked.
- On average it takes 2 days for the video to become  trending, majority of videos trend for only 1 day.
- People and Blogs have by far the biggest number of trending videos in the first day, Entertainment anf News and Politics are also up there. Movies do not really trend at all.
- <b>Most common words in most disliked category News and Politics</b> have for some reason a lot of kazach/tajik words. You can also see names frequent in the media like German Gref, Putin, Medvedev, Rogozin. Among other interesting words are USA, theft, capital.
- The <b>majority of videos with disabled comments belong to politics</b>.

</details>


|[Go see full project!](https://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/kate-chunosova/Personal_projects/blob/master/YouTube_Video_Analysis/YouTube_Sent_Analysis.ipynb)|
